content: Similar in that they more or less accurately describe different ways I've heard people get it. For me it was mostly "thinking about it" like analysis or talk therapy, then the final lightbulb moment was a realization in thought that triggered it. Others who sort of arrive there through formal meditation it seems more akin to an observation, but they are forms of realizing like "*OH* this is what I am".

When I say 'ever' I mean it has never been interrupted. 

*So what should I possibly answer to this question?*

You can tell something isn't yourself because you will not be satisfied with the answer and not perceive it as correct. At your core, you know exactly what "Me" is because it is the only thing that you are and all that ever exists for you, but layered on top of that is the idea you're something else. 

What eventually has to be realized is that *everything* you believe you are is not yourself because all forms of thought are produced by "Me" and can't contain its own source. It's exactly like me asking "look at the person who's seeing" or "what does sound itself sound like?"

Because we haven't seen this limitation human being instead invent philosophy, religion, and spirituality to try to intellectually resolve self-identity when there isn't actually one. You have to realize, observe, or have the thoughts that lead you to see *why* there is no thought based identity that you've invented for yourself and can never be one for it to dissolve automatically.

*the task you gave your disciples is simple* 

kms don't ever say that I hate all of you (jk, unless...?)

"You gave an example: You're not a central banker, a central banker is an abstraction of you and your social identity, it's your self image."

Tru baybeee. 

To actually respond to what you're saying, there are no metrics that define "Me-ness".  The difficulty of self-realization is coming to the conclusion that there is absolutely nothing that is more primordial or insightful than "what 'Me' is exactly". 


You might hate it, but imagine you are the only human being on earth, and then you have to thinkg "fuck, I'm alive and I don't know why, what the frick is it that I'm experiencing as this human thing??" It is not an objective "ah yes, this is the behaviour of the human", it is "what is actually what I experience right now when I open my eyes and is the only thing I ever experience?
